title: Trump Administration Blocks Ukraine From Using US-Provided Long-Range Missiles on Strikes in Russian Territory: REPORT
description: Did the US pull the plug on Ukrainian strikes in Russian territory using the US-provided missiles?
content:
Did the US pull the plug on Ukrainian strikes in Russian territory using the US-provided missiles?

After the historic summit between Donald J. Trump and Vladimir Putin in Alaska, it was stipulated that Russia and Ukraine would negotiate the next meeting of Putin with Kiev leader Volodymyr Zelensky.

To the surprise of absolutely no one, Zelensky and his Euro-Globalist mentors have muddied the waters considerably – while Russia is putting its foot down and insisting on their long-known demands.

From a distance, Trump has decried the lack of progress, and said that in two weeks he may impose sanctions and tariffs (on Russia), or else he may pull back from the peace process and let it play out.

Then, yesterday, the Kiev regime attacked the Druzhba pipeline for the third time, cutting the flow of Russian crude oil to Hungary and Slovakia, endangering their energy security.

Trump responded to a complaint by his long-time ally Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán saying that he was ‘very angry about it’.

Coincidence or not, here’s what was reported today, initially by the WSJ (behind a paywall):

“The Pentagon has been quietly blocking Ukraine from using U.S.-made long-range Army Tactical Missile Systems (ATACMS) to strike targets inside Russia, limiting Kyiv’s ability to employ these weapons in its defense against Moscow’s invasion, the Wall Street Journal reported on Saturday, citing U.S. officials.

The news came as U.S. President Donald Trump has grown more frustrated publicly over the three-year-old war and his inability to secure a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine.”

“Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has final say over use of the long-range weapons, the Journal said.

Neither Ukraine’s presidential office nor the defense ministry immediately responded to Reuters’ request for a comment outside business hours. The White House and the Pentagon also did not immediately respond to requests for comment.”
links: https://truthsocial.com/share?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thegatewaypundit.com%2F2025%2F08%2Ftrump-administration-blocks-ukraine-using-us-provided-long%2F&title=Trump Administration Blocks Ukraine From Using US-Provided Long-Range Missiles on Strikes in Russian Territory: REPORT
summary: The US has reportedly blocked Ukraine from using US-provided long-range missiles in strikes in Russian territory. This comes after the US President expressed frustration over the lack of progress in the peace process between Russia and Ukraine. This follows a recent attack by the Kiev regime on the Druzhba pipeline, cutting the flow of Russian crude oil to Hungary and Slovakia. The Pentagon has reportedly been quietly blocking Ukraine's use of these weapons, limiting their use in defense against Russia's invasion.
shortSummary: The US has blocked Ukraine from using US-provided missiles in Russian territory, amid escalating tensions and Kiev's attacks on a crucial pipeline.

scraped_sources.text:
Ukraine bites the hands that feed it.
As we reported three days ago, the Ukrainians have started attacking the Druzhba pipeline that transports Russian crude oil to Hungary and Slovakia.
While strikes on energy infrastructure have become commonplace, this specific pipeline is the lifeline for the Hungarian and Slovak economies.
Hungarian Foreign Minister Péter Szijjártó took to X, and sais that the ‘strike against our energy security is outrageous and unacceptable!’
The Ukrainian FM Andrii Sybiha was ironic, and told his counterpart ‘You can now send your complaints—and threats—to your friends in Moscow’.
Szijjártó responded with fire, saying:
“Fact 1: Russia has supplied oil to Hungary for decades via the Druzhba pipeline. This is in Hungary’s interest.
Fact 2: Ukraine attacks this pipeline, and because of these Ukrainian strikes, oil supplies to Hungary are repeatedly cut off. This is against Hungary’s interest.
As Hungary’s Foreign Minister my mandate is clear: Hungary’s interest comes first. Period.
And let’s not forget: a significant part of Ukraine’s electricity comes from Hungary…”
Yes, you read it right: Ukraine disrupts the energy security of a country who sends electricity to make up for its destroyed infrastructure!
So, today, Kiev unleashed a third strike on the Druzhba pipeline – and again the flow of Russian crude oil to Budapest and Bratislava has been interrupted.
This time, Prime Minister Victor Orbán took to social media to protest.
“Five days ago, just before the historic meeting between President Trump and Putin in Alaska, Ukraine carried out drone strikes on the Druzhba oil pipeline in Russia. This pipeline supplies Hungary and Slovakia, two countries that have no other means of importing crude oil. Hungary supports Ukraine with electricity and petrol; in return they bomb pipeline that supply us. Very unfriendly move! We wish President Trump every success in his pursuit for peace!”
His complaint was heard (read) by US President Donald J. Trump, who posted a handwritten response.
‘Viktor, I do not like hearing this – I am very angry about it. Tell Slovakia. You are my great friend’, Trump wrote.’
It’s unclear what can Trump do about at this juncture, but he is at least exposed to a window on the behavior by the Kiev regime.
Read more:

argos_summary: The article reports that the U.S. has quietly restricted Ukraine’s use of U.S.-made ATACMS long‑range missiles, limiting Kyiv’s ability to strike targets in Russia, a move that has frustrated President Trump. Meanwhile, Ukraine has carried out a third strike on the Druzhba pipeline, cutting Russian crude oil flow to Hungary and Slovakia, prompting Hungarian officials to condemn the attacks and accuse Ukraine of undermining energy security. Trump publicly expressed anger over the pipeline strikes and hinted at possible sanctions or a withdrawal from the peace process if progress stalls. The piece highlights tensions between U.S. policy, Ukrainian military actions, and European energy concerns.
